name: Jang Yeong-sil
summary: Jang Yeong-sil was a renowned inventor and engineer during Korea's Joseon Dynasty. Despite his low social status as a government slave, his genius was recognized by King Sejong. He invented the automated water clock (Jagyeongnu), rain gauge (Cheugugi), and improved metal movable type printing. His innovations in astronomical instruments advanced Korean science significantly.
timeline: Appointed to royal court by King Sejong

name: Choe Mu-seon
summary: Choe Mu-seon was a Goryeo Dynasty military scientist who introduced gunpowder weapons to Korea. He learned gunpowder manufacturing techniques from a Chinese merchant and established Korea's first gunpowder factory. His weapons were crucial in defeating Japanese pirate (Wokou) invasions, fundamentally changing Korean naval warfare.
timeline: Learned gunpowder formula from Chinese merchant Li Yuan
Gunpowder weapons used at Battle of Jinpo

name: Heo Jun
summary: Heo Jun was a legendary Korean physician of the Joseon Dynasty who compiled the Dongui Bogam, one of the most important medical texts in East Asian history. This encyclopedic work systematized Korean, Chinese, and Japanese medical knowledge. It was designated a UNESCO Memory of the World document in 2009. He served as the royal physician to King Seonjo.
timeline: Attended King Seonjo during Imjin War
Dongui Bogam designated UNESCO Memory of the World

name: Woo Jang-chun
summary: Woo Jang-chun was a pioneering Korean-Japanese botanist and geneticist known for the Triangle of U theory explaining the genetic relationships among Brassica species. His work laid foundations for understanding polyploidy in plants and revolutionized crop breeding. He returned to Korea after World War II and contributed greatly to Korean agricultural development.
timeline: Published early research on Brassica genetics
Proposed the Triangle of U theory
Earned doctorate from Tokyo Imperial University
Developed improved vegetable varieties for Korea

name: Lee Hwi-so
summary: Lee Hwi-so (Benjamin W. Lee) was a brilliant Korean-American theoretical physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to particle physics. He played a key role in proving the renormalizability of gauge theories and predicting the charm quark. His work was foundational for the Standard Model of particle physics. He died tragically in a car accident at age 42.
timeline: Moved to the United States for graduate study
Earned PhD from University of Pennsylvania
Published influential work on spontaneous symmetry breaking
Proved renormalizability of gauge theories with Zinn-Justin
Joined Fermilab as head of theoretical physics
Died in car accident in Illinois

name: Seok Ju-myeong
summary: Seok Ju-myeong was a pioneering Korean botanist and plant taxonomist who documented Korean native plant species during the Japanese colonial period. He worked tirelessly to establish a Korean-language botanical nomenclature system, rejecting the Japanese naming conventions imposed on Korean flora. His efforts preserved Korean botanical identity.
timeline: Began botanical surveys of Korean mountains
Continued clandestine research during Japanese suppression

name: Choi Hyung-sup
summary: Choi Hyung-sup was the father of Korean industrial engineering, particularly in steel and metallurgy. He played a pivotal role in the establishment of POSCO (Pohang Iron and Steel Company), which became one of the world's largest steel producers. His expertise in metallurgical engineering transformed South Korea's industrial landscape.
timeline: Began advising Korean government on industrialization
Key role in planning POSCO steel works
Continued contribution to Korean heavy industry

name: Yi Cheon
summary: Yi Cheon was a Joseon Dynasty military engineer and inventor who worked alongside Jang Yeong-sil. He developed advanced firearms, cannons, and military technologies for the Joseon army. He also contributed to the creation of astronomical instruments and the improvement of metal movable type. He served in various high-ranking military and engineering positions.

name: Kim Jeong-ho
summary: Kim Jeong-ho was a legendary Joseon Dynasty cartographer who created the Daedongyeojido, the most detailed and accurate map of Korea in the pre-modern era. Using woodblock printing techniques, he produced a 22-panel folding map covering the entire Korean Peninsula with remarkable precision. His cartographic methods were centuries ahead of Korean mapmaking traditions.
timeline: Completed Daedongyeojido (Great Map of the East)

name: Lee Tai-young
summary: Lee Tai-young was Korea's first female lawyer and judge, and a pioneering advocate for women's legal rights. While primarily known as a legal figure, she conducted systematic research on family law reform. She founded the Korea Legal Aid Center for Family Relations and fought for gender equality in Korean law throughout her career.
timeline: Born in Unju, North Pyeongan Province
Entered Seoul National University Law School
Founded Korea Legal Aid Center for Family Relations
Dismissed from bench for democracy activism

name: Park Chul-jae
summary: Park Chul-jae was a pioneering Korean nuclear physicist who contributed to the development of South Korea's nuclear energy program. He helped establish the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute (KAERI) and trained a generation of Korean nuclear scientists. His work was instrumental in Korea becoming a major nuclear power technology exporter.
timeline: Studied nuclear physics in the United States
Returned to Korea to develop nuclear program
Led first Korean nuclear reactor research
Kori Nuclear Power Plant Unit 1 began operation

name: Cho Baek-hyun
summary: Cho Baek-hyun was one of Korea's first modern chemists and a pioneer of chemistry education in Korea. He studied chemistry in Japan and Germany before returning to Korea to establish chemistry departments at Korean universities. He published the first Korean-language chemistry textbooks and trained the first generation of Korean chemists.
timeline: Returned to Korea to teach chemistry
Helped establish chemistry programs at Seoul National University

name: Lee Won-chul
summary: Lee Won-chul was a pioneering Korean physicist who earned his doctorate in cosmic ray physics from Japan's Osaka Imperial University. He became one of the founders of modern physics education in South Korea and helped establish the Korean Physical Society. He mentored many of Korea's early generation of physicists.
timeline: Graduated from Keijo Imperial University (now SNU)
Earned PhD in cosmic ray physics from Osaka
Founded physics department at Seoul National University

name: Gwon Geun
summary: Gwon Geun was a Joseon Dynasty Confucian scholar and astronomer who created the Cheonsang Yeolcha Bunyajido, one of the oldest surviving astronomical star maps in the world. Carved in stone in 1395, this star chart mapped 1,467 stars in 282 constellations. His astronomical work bridged Goryeo and Joseon dynasty scientific traditions.
timeline: Created Cheonsang Yeolcha Bunyajido star map

name: Kim Yong-gwan
summary: Kim Yong-gwan was a pioneering Korean electrical engineer who contributed to the development of South Korea's telecommunications infrastructure. He helped establish the Korean Institute of Electrical Engineers and led the modernization of Korea's electrical grid during the rapid industrialization period of the 1960s-1970s.
timeline: Contributed to Korean semiconductor industry foundations
Established engineering standards for Korean industry

name: Yun Il-seon
summary: Yun Il-seon was a pioneering Korean medical researcher who established modern medical research institutions in South Korea. He served as president of Seoul National University Hospital and contributed to the development of Korean medical education standards. His research in internal medicine helped modernize Korean healthcare systems.
timeline: Graduated from Seoul National University Medical School
Studied medicine in the United States
Returned to Korea as medical professor
Served as president of SNU Hospital

name: Seo Ho-su
summary: Seo Ho-su was a late Joseon Dynasty scholar who advanced mathematical and astronomical knowledge in Korea through his study of Western scientific works transmitted via China. He translated and adapted European mathematical texts and astronomical methods, contributing to the modernization of Korean scientific thought during the Silhak (practical learning) movement.
timeline: Began studying Western mathematics via Chinese texts

name: Hong Dae-yong
summary: Hong Dae-yong was a Joseon Dynasty Silhak scholar who independently proposed the heliocentric model and Earth's rotation. He built an astronomical observatory and created a water clock. He visited Beijing in 1765 where he engaged with Western astronomy through Jesuit missionaries. His Uisan Mundap argued for Earth's rotation before this was widely accepted in East Asia.
timeline: Wrote Uisan Mundap arguing for Earth's rotation
Advanced heliocentric ideas in Korean scholarship

name: Na Gyeong-seok
summary: Na Gyeong-seok was one of Korea's first modern biologists who conducted systematic zoological surveys of the Korean Peninsula. He documented numerous species of Korean fauna and established biological research programs at Korean universities. His surveys created baseline biodiversity data that remains valuable for Korean ecological research.
timeline: Began systematic surveys of Korean fauna
Published catalogs of Korean animal species
Established biology department at Korean university

name: Lee Seung-gi
summary: Lee Seung-gi was a Korean chemist who invented Vinalon, one of the first synthetic fibers developed outside the West. He synthesized the fiber from polyvinyl alcohol in 1939 while working at Kyoto Imperial University. After the Korean War, he went to North Korea where Vinalon became the national fiber. His achievement demonstrated Korean capability in advanced chemistry.
timeline: Born in Damyang, Jeolla Province, Korea
Went to North Korea during Korean War
Vinalon factory opened in Hamhung, North Korea

name: Choi Gyu-ha
summary: Choi Gyu-ha was a pioneering Korean computer scientist who helped introduce computer technology to South Korea in the 1960s. He led early computing research at KAIST and helped establish Korea's first computer science programs. His work laid foundations for Korea's later emergence as a global technology powerhouse.
timeline: Studied engineering in the United States
Returned to Korea with computing expertise
Led computer science program development at KAIST

name: Song Sang-yong
summary: Song Sang-yong was Korea's foremost historian of science who documented the history of Korean scientific achievements. He authored numerous books on the history of science in Korea and East Asia. His scholarship brought international recognition to Korean contributions to science and technology throughout history.
timeline: Published first major work on Korean science history
Established history of science program at Seoul National University
Published comprehensive history of Korean science

name: Choe Seok-jeong
summary: Choe Seok-jeong was a Joseon Dynasty mathematician and prime minister who created orthogonal Latin squares, predating Euler's work by decades. His mathematical text Gusuryak contained the first known example of an orthogonal Latin square of order 9. He combined his mathematical genius with a distinguished political career.

name: Kim Si-seup
summary: Kim Si-seup was a Joseon Dynasty polymath known for his literary works and scientific curiosity. He was one of the Saeng Yuksin (Six Martyred Ministers) loyal to King Danjong. He wrote about natural phenomena, astronomical observations, and practical technologies. His Geumo Sinhwa is considered the first Korean novel.
timeline: Went into self-exile after Sejo's coup
Wandered Korea studying nature and science
Wrote Geumo Sinhwa (New Stories from Gold Turtle Mountain)
Lived as Buddhist monk studying natural philosophy

name: Yi Sugwang
summary: Yi Sugwang was a Joseon Dynasty scholar-diplomat who authored Jibong Yuseol, the first Korean encyclopedia covering science, technology, and natural phenomena. Through diplomatic missions to China, he introduced Western scientific concepts including the telescope, European geography, and Catholicism to Korea. His encyclopedia bridged Eastern and Western knowledge.
timeline: First diplomatic mission to Ming China
Second mission to China, encountered Western science
Published Jibong Yuseol (Topical Discourses of Jibong)
Introduced Western geographical knowledge to Korea
Continued scholarly work and government service

name: Jeong Yak-yong
summary: Jeong Yak-yong (Dasan) was a towering Joseon Dynasty polymath and the greatest figure of the Silhak movement. He designed the Geojunggi crane used to build Hwaseong Fortress, wrote over 500 books on science, medicine, law, and governance. His practical scientific approach anticipated modernization and remains deeply influential in Korean intellectual history.
timeline: Designed Geojunggi crane for Hwaseong construction

name: Choe Han-gi
summary: Choe Han-gi was a late Joseon Dynasty scholar who attempted to integrate Western and Eastern scientific thought. His concept of 'gi' (vital force) as the basis of natural phenomena anticipated some ideas of modern physics. He wrote extensively on astronomy, meteorology, and medicine, promoting empirical approaches to knowledge.
timeline: Published Singi Tongchi (comprehensive theory of vital force)

name: Lee Tae-gyu
summary: Lee Tae-gyu was a pioneering Korean physical chemist who made significant contributions to the theory of absolute reaction rates. He worked with Henry Eyring at Princeton on transition state theory, co-authoring influential papers. He later returned to Korea to help build the nation's chemistry research infrastructure and served as president of the Korean Chemical Society.
timeline: Born in Yesan, South Chungcheong Province
Graduated from Hiroshima Higher Normal School
Worked with Henry Eyring at Princeton
Established chemistry research at Seoul National University
Moved to KAIST to develop chemistry research

name: Kwon Suk-il
summary: Kwon Suk-il was a Korean materials scientist who contributed to the development of Korea's semiconductor industry. His research on silicon materials processing helped lay the technological foundation for companies like Samsung Electronics to become global leaders in semiconductor manufacturing.
timeline: Contributed to Korean semiconductor industry growth

name: Kim Ho-gil
summary: Kim Ho-gil was a Korean aerospace engineer who helped establish South Korea's space program. He worked on developing Korea's first sounding rockets and contributed to the KSLV (Korea Space Launch Vehicle) program. His work laid the groundwork for Korea's modern space capabilities.

name: Lee Jong-wook
summary: Lee Jong-wook was a Korean physician who served as Director-General of the World Health Organization from 2003 until his death in 2006. He launched the '3 by 5' initiative aiming to provide antiretroviral treatment to 3 million HIV/AIDS patients by 2005. His leadership emphasized health equity and access to treatment in developing nations.
timeline: Graduated from Seoul National University Medical School
Led WHO's Global Programme for Vaccines
Expanded WHO's response to avian influenza

name: Hyun Shin-gyu
summary: Hyun Shin-gyu was a Korean agricultural scientist who developed improved rice varieties that increased grain yields in South Korea. His plant breeding research during the 1960s and 1970s was part of Korea's agricultural modernization, helping the country achieve food self-sufficiency. He trained many Korean agricultural researchers.
timeline: Began rice breeding research in South Korea

name: Choi Kyu-nam
summary: Choi Kyu-nam was one of the first Korean geologists who systematically surveyed and mapped the geological formations of the Korean Peninsula. He established geology as an academic discipline in Korea and discovered several mineral deposits important for Korean industrial development.
timeline: Began geological surveys of Korean Peninsula
Established geology department at Seoul National University

name: Yu Geum
summary: Yu Geum was a late Goryeo Dynasty astronomer who worked on calendar reform and astronomical observations. He helped create improved calendrical systems that more accurately tracked solar and lunar cycles. His astronomical work bridged the transition from Goryeo to Joseon Dynasty scientific traditions.

name: Kim Yeon
summary: Kim Yeon was a Goryeo Dynasty military inventor who created the Hwacha, a multiple rocket launcher system. The Hwacha could fire up to 200 rocket-propelled arrows simultaneously, making it one of the most devastating weapons of its era. It was used extensively against Japanese invasions and became an iconic Korean military invention.
timeline: Improved Hwacha designed under King Sejong
Recorded in Gukjo Orye Seorye (national records)
Hwacha used effectively during Imjin War
Battle of Haengju â€” Hwacha proved decisive

name: Song I-yeong
summary: Song I-yeong was a Joseon Dynasty astronomer and horologist who constructed Korea's first known astronomical clock using Western mechanical techniques. He learned clock-making from Jesuit missionaries' texts transmitted through China. His astronomical instruments combined traditional Korean astronomy with European mechanical principles.
timeline: Built astronomical clock for the Joseon court

name: Lee Cheon
summary: Lee Cheon was a Joseon Dynasty pharmacologist who compiled detailed records of Korean medicinal herbs and their therapeutic uses. Working under royal patronage, he systematized Korean traditional medicine knowledge and contributed to the pharmaceutical traditions that would later be incorporated into Heo Jun's Dongui Bogam.

name: Lee Chun-yeong
summary: Lee Chun-yeong was a Korean virologist who made significant contributions to the control of infectious diseases in South Korea. He helped establish modern virology research in Korea and contributed to vaccination programs that greatly reduced childhood diseases. His research on hemorrhagic fever was particularly important for Korean public health.
timeline: Began virology research during Korean War
Led Korean epidemic disease control efforts

name: Kim Bong-han
summary: Kim Bong-han was a North Korean anatomist who claimed to have discovered a new circulatory system (Bonghan system/primo-vascular system) corresponding to acupuncture meridians. Though his original claims were controversial and poorly documented, renewed research in the 21st century has identified thread-like structures that some researchers associate with his observations.
timeline: Began medical research in North Korea

name: Ha Bu-yeong
summary: Ha Bu-yeong was a pioneering Korean mathematician who helped establish modern mathematics education in South Korea. He contributed to algebra and number theory research while building the institutional foundations for Korean mathematical scholarship. He mentored many of Korea's first generation of professional mathematicians.
timeline: Began teaching at Seoul National University

name: Kim Jeong-ryeom
summary: Kim Jeong-ryeom was a Korean chemical engineer who played a key role in establishing South Korea's petrochemical industry during the 1960s and 1970s. He helped plan and build major chemical plants that formed the backbone of Korea's industrial economy and contributed to the country's rapid economic development.

name: Seong Ju-deok
summary: Seong Ju-deok was a Joseon Dynasty astronomer and mathematician who improved calendrical calculations and astronomical instruments. He served in the Gwansanggam (Bureau of Astronomy) and contributed to the accuracy of the Joseon court's astronomical observations and calendar systems.

name: Nam Byeong-woo
summary: Nam Byeong-woo was a Korean electronics engineer who helped establish South Korea's electronics industry. He contributed to the development of early Korean radio and television broadcasting technology and trained engineers who would later lead Korea's consumer electronics revolution.
timeline: Helped develop Korean consumer electronics industry

name: Heo Gyun
summary: Heo Gyun was a Joseon Dynasty polymath, brother of the famous poet Heo Nanseolheon. Besides his literary fame, he was deeply interested in astronomy, geography, and technology. He compiled works on military science and geography and advocated for scientific modernization in Joseon society. He was executed for allegedly plotting rebellion.
timeline: Wrote Hong Gildong Jeon (first Korean novel in Hangul)
Compiled works on geography and military science

name: Park Dong-in
summary: Park Dong-in was a pioneering Korean oceanographer who helped establish marine science research in South Korea. He led early oceanographic surveys of the seas around the Korean Peninsula and helped found the Korea Institute of Ocean Science and Technology. His research was fundamental to Korea's marine resource development.

name: Choi Seung-hee
summary: Choi Seung-hee was a Korean microbiologist who scientifically studied Korean fermented foods, particularly kimchi and doenjang (fermented soybean paste). Her research documented the beneficial microorganisms in traditional Korean fermentation processes and helped establish the scientific basis for Korean food science.
timeline: Published studies on lactic acid bacteria in Korean foods
Contributed to Korean food safety standards

name: An Sang-su
summary: An Sang-su was a Korean entomologist who systematically studied insects of the Korean Peninsula and developed biological pest control methods for Korean agriculture. His research on insect taxonomy and ecology contributed significantly to Korean agricultural productivity and environmental protection.
timeline: Began insect surveys of Korean Peninsula
